But to this it may be answrd, that by the same 
argumt wee may conclude against the possibly 
aeternall  Duration, because no number of Days or 
Years or Ages can compleat it. Another argument 
I have heard urged, that if the number of fixt starrs 
were more than finite, the whole superficies of their 
apparent sphere would be luminous, for that those 
shinig bodies would be more in number than there are seconds 
of a degree in the area of the whole sphericall surface.
which I think cannot be denied; But if we suppose 
all the fixt starrs to be as far from one another, as the nearest of ym from 
the Sunn; that is if we may suppose the Sunn to be one 
of them, at a <s>double <\s> greater distance their Disks and Light will 
be diminisht in the proportion of squares, and the space 
to contain them will be encreasd in the same proportion;
so that in each Spherick surface the number of starrs it might 
contain will be as the biquadrate of their distances.
put then the distances immensely great, as wee are well 
assured they cannot but be, and from thence by an obvious 
<u>calculus <\u>, it will be found, that as the diameters of the 
fixt starrs diminish, the intervalls between them must en 
crease. Add to this, that the more remote starrs, and 
those few short of the remotest, vanish even in the most 
[illegible] Telescopes by reason of their extream minuteness; so 
that, though it were true that some such starrs are 
in such a place, yet <s>its <\s> their beams aided by any help yet 
known are not sufficient to move our sense; after the 
same manner as a small Telescopicall fixt starr is
by no means perceivable to the naked Eye.

Dr Halley on the 
Starrs 
read March 9
1720
